trial_identification.studytitle: Quantifying the Physical, Cognitive and Social Activity Levels Early After Stroke: How Enriched is the Acute Stroke Environment?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Quantifying Activity Levels of Survivors Early After Stroke

interventions.interventions: Observational Study- Quantifying activity using direct observation techniques (behavioral mapping). Patients will be observed on a randomly selected weekday every 5 minutes for 55 minutes during each of the following time periods (i) 8-11am, (ii) 11am-2pm, (iii) 2pm-5pm and (iv) 5pm-8pm. Patients will be observed for one day within the first 21 days following their stroke.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Percentage of the day spent in activity using behavioural mapping techniques on one weekday during their admission within the acute neurology ward/stroke unit, < or = to 21 since their initial stroke. They will be observed on a randomly selected weekday every 5 minutes for 55 minutes during each of the following time periods (i) 8-11am, (ii) 11am-2pm, (iii) 2pm-5pm and (iv) 5pm-8pm.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: > 2 days and < or = 21 days post stroke

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Experience of stroke patients recovering in acute stroke setting early after stroke using qualitative in -depth interview techniques. They will be interviewed within the first 21 days post stroke and whilst they are still an inpatient within the ward.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: > 2 days and < or = 21 days post stroke

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Experience of staff working in an acute stroke setting with patients recovering very early after stroke using qualitative in -depth interview techniques.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At some stage during the conduct of the observational study. Data collection is expected to be completed by August 2014.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Admitted for recent stroke Estimated length of stay > 2 days
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: premorbid modified Rankin Scale score > or = 3.

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Activity, location and people present for each participant will be expressed as a percentage of the total number of observations made. A Pearson productmoment correlation coefficient (r) will be calculated to assess the relationship between activity level and (i) stroke severity (ii) motor function (motor component of NIHSS), (iii) cognitive function (cognitive component of NIHSS), and (iv) mood (HADS). The 95% confidence intervals (CI) for Pearsons r will be calculated using Fishers transformation. All analyses will be performed using STATA 13.0. Qualitative data will be analysed using an inductive thematic approach with the use of constant comparison.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Acute stroke patients spend as little as 13% the day in physical activity (1), but how much of their day is spent participating in cognitive and social activities remains unknown. The proposed observational study seeks to determine the: (i) physical, cognitive and social activity levels of patients very early after stroke, (ii) relationship between stroke severity and activity levels, (iii) proportion of acute stroke patients capable of engaging in greater activity and, (iv) barriers and facilitators to activity in an acute neurology unit. This is important preliminary work required to inform the translation of the use of an enriched environment into the acute setting.
